Redundancy

Sign up for emails about redundancy

The big questions

What is redundancy pay?

Redundancy payment is money employees are entitled to when they lose their job through redundancy.

What does the law say?

Employers must pay employees when they are made redundant, uness their contract says something different.

Can I claim redundancy pay

Yes

If you have been an employee at the same place for two years or more
• That can include time off for parental leave or sick leave
• And swapping jobs in the same firm
• It’s fine if you’ve been part-time too
• But it cannot include any time you’ve spent training

No

If you’re a...
• Casual worker, like a ‘zero hour’ contractor, a freelancer, or anyone who isn’t an official employee, paying tax at source
• Former registered dock worder or share fisherman
• Crown servant or member of the armed forces or police services
• An apprentice who’s still training
• A domestic servant who is a member of the employer’s immediate family

What is redundancy pay made up of?

Redundancy pay is made up of different elements outlined here.

How much you get depends on your age. To work it out roughly, first, tell us how old you are...

How much will I get paid

To work out what you’ll get yourself, use the government’s redundancy pay calculator, on the government website.

Top tip: Always check your contract. It might say something different. If you’re not sure, ask the person who employed you for a copy.

When will I get paid?

You’ll get it all in one lump sum, after you have worked your notice period. If you just walk out without working your notice, you won’t get paid!
